injury_risk_explanation: Excessive shoulder rotation and bent elbow at impact create significant internal shoulder stress and increase risk of rotator cuff injuries and elbow strain.

critical_issues.injury_risk: Excessive internal rotation causes abnormal stress on rotator cuff muscles and labrum, increasing risk of shoulder impingement, strains, or tears.
critical_issues.correction: Maintain a more neutral shoulder position at contact, limit rotation to 30-40° internally from neutral
critical_issues.drill: Shoulder rotation drill against wall: Stand facing wall, throw forehand smash with controlled 45° shoulder rotation without full body twist

critical_issues.problem: Too bent at impact (147.7° vs reference 165.8°)
critical_issues.injury_risk: Bent elbow at full extension increases valgus stress on elbow joint, raising risk of UCL (ulnar collateral ligament) strain or tennis elbow.
critical_issues.correction: Extend elbow fully at contact point while maintaining racket face stability
critical_issues.drill: Elbow extension drill: Perform smash with racket held at 45°, focus on extending elbow fully without wrist bend

critical_issues.problem: Contact point too low (-0.082 vs reference -0.153)
critical_issues.injury_risk: Lower contact point forces excessive trunk lean and shoulder elevation, increasing torque on shoulder joint and neck muscles.
critical_issues.correction: Time jump higher or initiate earlier for optimal head-high contact point
critical_issues.drill: Vertical smash drill: Practice hitting smash at head level using a high serve feed

positive_feedback: Good core engagement and racket speed observed. Your arm extension shows potential for power development if angles are corrected. Maintaining racket face stability is a positive technical foundation.
summary: Significant form adjustments needed to prevent shoulder/elbow injuries and maximize power. Focus on neutral shoulder position and full elbow extension. With proper technique correction, you can develop powerful, safe smashes.
